Merge pull request #27408 Avoid file generation with `gradle init` when dialog is cancelled

Fixes https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/18080

This PR is initially based on https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/23126. However, significant refactoring of the `Wrapper` task was required, so it was easier to start from a fresh branch.

In this PR, `init` task no longer depends on the `wrapper` task. Instead, it uses the shared logic to output the wrapper files. This makes sure, when the `init` task gets cancelled, no files are generated, including the wrapper files.

Co-authored-by: Alex Semin <asemin@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #27368 Wire dependency resolution for dependency mapping

Version mapping and dependency mapping previously did not properly wire dependency resolution. Instead, they resolved configurations eagerly instead of through providers.

This properly uses providers to wire resolution results all the way down to the dependency mapping resolvers.

This does not yet actually declare resolution properly, as that is blocked by #27255

This change primarily relies on a new provider, MergeProvider, which can accept a list of providers and provides a list of the resolved provider values

Merge pull request #27370 Deprecate publishing maven dependency with differing artifact name

Currently, when publishing to maven, Gradle interprets an artifact with an explicit name as a dependency on a module name equal to that artifact name. This is an incorrect interpretation, as this changes the original declared coordinates.

This ability to declare artifacts with name different than the module's name is a feature only supported by Ivy. This should always have been an error.

Co-authored-by: Justin Van Dort <jvandort@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #26993 Make fetching `IdeaProject` model Isolated Projects-compatible for Java projects

This PR introduces a new model builder for the `IdeaProject` model that is compatible with Isolated Projects.

The new builder works by requesting intermediate isolated models for individuals IDEA modules, and then aggregates them into the top-level `IdeaProject` model.

This builder requires applying `IdeaPlugin` to all projects in a build. The plugin itself is not Isolated Projects compatible, and not even Configuration Cache compatible. However, the main source of incompatibility lies in the conventions for certain DSL properties. The new model builder fixes this by fetching the required data via isolated intermediate models.

This has a downside, that in some places it effectively reimplements the convention computation logic of the `IdeaPlugin`. In the future, the conventions should be migrated to use shared data and become IP-compatible themselves.

Fixes #26614

Co-authored-by: Alex Semin <asemin@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #27264 Gradle-init source package property

Fixes https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/26219

The `gradle init` task behavior is changed in the following way:

- Source package can be specified via Gradle property
	- Using `org.gradle.buildinit.source.package` Gradle property users can specify package name to use for new projects generated by `gradle init`
	- The package name can be also empty, resulting in an [unnamed package](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-7.html#jls-7.4.2) for sources in subprojects that don't have their own package prefixes like `app` or `lib`
	- *Before: it was not possible to specify a the source package like that*

- When no source package is specified (neither via `init --package` nor via Gradle property)
	- Interactive dialog does request to provide it
	- A fixed package name `org.example` is used: `org.example.Main`
	- For multi-project builds, it's used as a prefix, e.g. `org.example.app.App`
	- *Before: uses had to answer an interactive question with a default value generated from project name, e.g. `my-toy-project` resulted in `my.toy.project` package default*

- For new projects, convention plugins generated in `buildSrc` or `build-logic`
	- Have a fixed name prefix `buildlogic`, e.g. `buildlogic.java-common-conventions.gradle.kts`
	- *Before: the source package name was used, e.g. `my.toy.project.java-common-conventions.gradle.kts`*

- For Maven-to-Gradle conversions, convention plugins generated in `buildSrc` or `build-logic`
	- Have a fixed name prefix `buildlogic`, e.g. `buildlogic.java-common-conventions.gradle.kts`
	- *Before: the Maven's root project group id was used, e.g. `my.toy.project.java-common-conventions.gradle.kts`*

Co-authored-by: Alex Semin <asemin@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #27016 Filter instrumentation and bytecode upgrade interceptors

Now interceptors can be filtered with:
- `BytecodeInterceptorRequest.INSTRUMENTATION_ONLY` -> instrumentation only
- `BytecodeInterceptorRequest.ALL` -> instrumentation + bytecode upgrades

There are two main parts:

1. Annotation processor changes: Now you can add type of interceptor to the class, e.g.:
```
@SpecificJvmCallInterceptors(generatedClassName = "SomeName", type = BytecodeInterceptorType.INSTRUMENTATION)
class MyInterceptorDeclarations {}
```
By default interceptor is of type `INSTRUMENTATION`. Annotation processor then adds a marker interface to the interceptor, so we can filter interceptors at Gradle instrumentation.

Additionally you can now also use `@InjectVisitorContext` and inject `BytecodeInterceptorRequest` as parameter. That is needed only to instrument `ScriptBytecodeAdapter`, so there is no other use case.
See changes in `:internal-instrumentation-processor`.

2. Gradle runtime changes:
We can now filter interceptors, by passing `BytecodeInterceptorRequest` to `InstrumentingClassTransform`. See changes in `:core`.

This request is then passed down to different handle methods so we can filter interceptors. Ideally we would have some kind of a "context" object here, but since we have to generate bytecode with such parameter, it's a bit easier to just use enum for now. But feel free to suggest a different approach.

Co-authored-by: Anže Sodja <asodja@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #27036 Parallel intermediate model fetching

Introduces the ability to fetch intermediate models in parallel via `IntermediateToolingModelProvider`.
This has a side effect, that project configuration for the target projects can happen in parallel as well.

Fetching may still fallback to sequential behavior, if the overall parallel Tooling API action running is disabled.
This is required to be able to sometime in the future replace vanilla model builders with their Isolated Project-safe counterparts, without causing unexpected parallel configuration of projects.

### Reviewing cheatsheet

Before merging the PR, comments starting with
- ❌ ❓**must** be fixed
- 🤔 💅 **should** be fixed
- 💭 **may** be fixed
- 🎉 celebrate happy things

Co-authored-by: Alex Semin <asemin@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #26884 Update transformed artifacts to not identify based on IvyArtifactName

We want to move away from IvyArtifactName. Instead create `TransformedComponentFileArtifactIdentifier` and identify based on original and current filename

Since artifact identifier toString/getDisplayName is not consistent across implementations, we update some tests to explicitly verify artifact file name and component ID. This simplifies the resolveTestFixture, which was originally testing artifact displayName. It instead verifies file name, a more valuable check.

Further:
* We attempt to avoid implicit calls to toString for artifactIDs in production code by explicitly calling getDisplayName
* We remove the toString method on IvyArtifactName in favor of an explicit getDisplayName. This allows us to better track where this is getting called (allowing us to begin reducing its usage)
* Separate ResolvedArtifact implementation from PreResolvedResolvableArtifact. ResolvedArtifact is a legacy type and this allows greater separation between legacy and internal modeling

Merge pull request #24943 Canonicalize "." and ".." segments in RelativePaths

Fixes #5748

### Context
As documented in #5748, Sync and Copy tasks can have buggy behaviors (such as deleting copied files) when RelativePath objects refer to the same path but consist of a different list of segments. This can happen in particular when "." and ".." are used in path segments.

Avoid this situation by canonicalizing RelativePaths as they are created, so that "." is not used and ".." only appears at the beginning of a path.

Merge pull request #26849 Implement MavenResolveTestFixture

This test fixture leverages Maven's public APIs for performing dependency resolution with its artifact repository engine. We skip running Maven entirely since that requires downloading a Maven distribution, which itself downloads plugins upon startup. This approach is more flexible for future expansion since it offers the ability to traverse the resolved graph itself, in-process This approach is much faster than running maven in a forked process or running MavenCli embedded.

Fixes #26826

Merge pull request #26471 Deprecate depending on resolved configuration

In some edge-case scenarios, it is possible to construct a graph where the configuration being resolved is selected as a variant. Needing to support this edge case makes it very difficult to separate the implementations of resolvable and consumable configurations.

We deprecate this behavior so that in Gradle 9+ we can more easily separate how resolvable and consumable configurations are implemented.

Co-authored-by: Justin Van Dort <jvandort@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #26585 Fix public API definitions

This PR updates the definition of the Gradle Public API to match the existing state of the project.
It also fixes other places in the project that normally must be synced to the public API definition.

I took the state of the public API definition and used it in a Bash script to find any packages that do not actually exist in the project anymore. This is done by running a ripgrep search for strings like `package org.gradle.env`.

<details>
  <summary>Stale package detection script</summary>

Note that you need [`ripgrep`](https://github.com/BurntSushi/ripgrep) installed to run this script.

```bash
#!/bin/bash

packages=(
    "org.gradle"
    "org.gradle.api"
    "org.gradle.authentication"
    "org.gradle.build"
    "org.gradle.buildinit"
    "org.gradle.caching"
    "org.gradle.concurrent"
    "org.gradle.deployment"
    "org.gradle.env"
    "org.gradle.external.javadoc"
    "org.gradle.ide"
    "org.gradle.includedbuild"
    "org.gradle.ivy"
    "org.gradle.jvm"
    "org.gradle.language"
    "org.gradle.maven"
    "org.gradle.nativeplatform"
    "org.gradle.normalization"
    "org.gradle.platform"
    "org.gradle.play"
    "org.gradle.plugin.devel"
    "org.gradle.plugin.repository"
    "org.gradle.plugin.use"
    "org.gradle.plugin.management"
    "org.gradle.plugins"
    "org.gradle.process"
    "org.gradle.testfixtures"
    "org.gradle.testing.jacoco"
    "org.gradle.tooling"
    "org.gradle.swiftpm"
    "org.gradle.model"
    "org.gradle.testkit"
    "org.gradle.testing"
    "org.gradle.vcs"
    "org.gradle.work"
    "org.gradle.workers"
    "org.gradle.util"
)

for package_name in "${packages[@]}"; do
    echo ""
    printf '%s\n' "Searching for '$package_name'"

    # Shows unique directories that contains files having a match for the package name
    rg --only-matching --with-filename "package $package_name" | \
        awk -F':' '{ print $1 }' | xargs -I {} dirname {} | sort -u | \
        rg 'src/main' | rg -v '/internal' | \
        awk 'NR==1 {prev=$0; next} {if (index($0, prev) != 1) print prev; prev=$0} END {print prev}'
done
```
</details>

These are the results that I got:
https://gist.github.com/alllex/f87a45f8a841bd3541845951043b8c69

They suggest that the following packages are not really part of the public API anymore. Either there are no classes at all in those packages, or they are not production classes (e.g. integration tests).

- `org.gradle.env`
- `org.gradle.includedbuild`
- `org.gradle.play`
- `org.gradle.plugin.repository`

Merge pull request #26620 Ship Gradle API Kotlin extensions JAR with the Gradle distribution

* First step for https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/26483

The code for Kotlin extensions generation that is now shared between the build logic building the Gradle distribution and the Gradle runtime for generated accessors has been moved from `:kotlin-dsl` to `:build-logic:kotlin-dsl-shared-runtime`.

The added weight to the Gradle distribution is ~145KB.

A couple subprojects of `:build-logic` have been pulled up to `:build-logic-common` in order to produce a valid Gradle module jar in `:build-logic`.

The generated extensions were never part of our binary compatibility check. This PR makes it possible but currently skips the `@Generated` code on purpose. A subsequent PR will deal with this.

****

This change makes first use faster by removing runtime processing. On my beefy m2 mac the gain is around 4s. On our performance test agents it is around 5s. On older or smaller machines, e.g. ephemeral CI agents, the impact will be larger.

****

This also makes iterating on our integration tests that use the Kotlin DSL faster because the extensions are compiled with a hot Kotlin compiler daemon as part of building the Gradle distribution vs. the cold embedded Kotlin compiler from the under-test Gradle runtime. Moreover, integration tests that require an isolated Gradle user home will simply not do that work anymore.

Co-authored-by: Paul Merlin <paul@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #25926 Do not store request details in local dependency metadata

These three fields were virtually unused. The attributes were unused, and the componentId and client configuration was only used for the rare error message where the dependency declared a target configuration AND that target configuration was not found in the target component. This case is rare, since it only occurs when variant-aware dependency resolution is disabled. And, in no other places do we print the declared configuration. Furthermore, the componentId is already printed in error messages where it was printed via the now-removed message, so no loss of information is apparent for the user.

Merge pull request #25778 Further consolidate Maven dependency mapping

Previous work separated component to an inner ComponentParser class. This PR extends this work
to move the ComponentParser to its own file, renamed to MavenComponentParser. This class contains
all logic requried to map a component's dependencies to their maven representation, including any
existing logic which lived in MavenPomFileGenerator.

Now, MavenPomFileGenerator is properly 'dumb'. It holds no state, encapulates minimal logic, and
serves only to map the Gradle types used to represent POM elements into the Maven types required for
writing POMs.

All logic for resolving project dependencies and performing version mapping has been consolidated into
MavenComponentParser. Now, most future work in this area will likely occur in this class and can avoid
widespread changes.

Three methods on GenerateMavenPom have been deprecated. One is a protected injection method, and two
are now unnecessary given that we preserve source variant information later in the version mapping
process. These methods only accepted internal types, meaning they should not have been used publicly,
and they also are unused by KMP and Android.

Merge pull request #25471 Avoid carrying current build op into worker context

Fixes https://github.com/gradle/gradle-private/issues/3891 for the most part, but further investigation into worker management code may be needed.

The current build operation for JavaCompile contains information about the project, and as such carrying it into a worker thread would result in permanent retention of that project and its entire build until the death of the worker. This information is likely unnecessary and confusing as the workers should be re-used across different projects and builds, so this PR prevents it from being added by clearing the thread local when spawning a new worker.

There is still a potential issue in that many new threads are spawned for every new worker, ~~and it seems like they don't all clean up properly over time. Despite many worker processes starting and stopping, the number of `Exec process thread`s present continues to climb, rather than stabilizing. This will eventually cause memory issues as well, but at a much slower pace.~~ This also affects all workers, not just the Java compilation one. Edit: this turns out to be untrue, but it can still climb to rather ridiculous numbers such as around ~150 workers and ~480 threads for them. It would be nice to try reducing these using async I/O to wait for processes or copy streams, which could be confined to as little as a single thread. This is tracked as https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/25488.

Co-authored-by: Octavia Togami <otogami@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #24826 Create initial JVM platform

Creates the initial platform directory structure by adding a `platforms` directory at the repo root, next to `subprojects`. Inside this dir is a directory for each platform. This PR creates the JVM platform directory, named `jvm`. We then moved the `:ear` project to that directory as a proof-of-concept.

The build is still not "platform aware". `subprojects.json` was updated to include these new platforms in their flattened form, so that there is no conceptual difference between declaring a subproject in `subprojects` and in `platforms/<platform>`.

This paves the way for other teams to start taking ownership of their subprojects and moving them into their corresponding platform directories. Future work will involve making the build more platform-aware, such as adding ArchTest rules for ensuring certain platforms do not access projects from other platforms. For example, the execution platform should not need to access anything from the JVM platform.

Merge pull request #25156 Extract logic that calculates diagnostics for a problem into a shared service

<!--- The issue this PR addresses -->
Fixes #?

### Context

This PR moves some common logic shared by exception analysis, deprecation logging and configuration cache problem reporting into a shared service. Previously this logic was duplicated by each of the callers and behaved differently.

The service also includes some basic logic to limit the number of stack traces that are collected when many problems are encountered during build execution. In this PR, the limit is hardcoded to 50, regardless of the problem type. This is intentionally very simple and can be improved in later PRs.

This PR does not attempt to move all of the duplicated logic into the service. For example, stack trace sanitization and duplicate problem handling are still implemented in different ways for each type of problem. This duplication can be addressed in later PRs.

This PR also includes some refactoring to use the configuration cache `ProblemFactory` in more places so that the shared logic is used for more kinds of configuration cache problems. There are still some places that still create `PropertyProblem` instances directly that need to be refactored.

Merge pull request #24843 Deprecate running test task successfully when no test executed

The `test` task currently succeeds when no test was executed, this is to be deprecated. Running the test task with no test to execute is typically caused by some misconfiguration, which is likely missed if `test` succeeds.

Note that "no test to execute" is different to "no test present". The former means there are test sources present, but they are not run (for example because of a missing test annotation or a different test framework.) The latter means there are no test sources present, in which case the `test` task is skipped.

`TestFilter::isFailOnNoMatchingTests` is not affected by this change. If `isFailOnNoMatchingTests == true`, `test` will fail and if `isFailOnNoMatchingTests == false`, `test` will run without a deprecation warning.

Most changes in this PR are updates of existing tests where tests were not run due to a missing test annotation or test method.

Relates to #7452

Co-authored-by: Julia Boes <jboes@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #24648 Introduce build path on BuildIdentifier

Historically, `BuildIdentifier` relied on the build name to identify the build. However, since the name of the build is not necessarily unique in the build tree, an actual identity path of the build has to be tracked separately.

Until recently, it was possible to convert a build name into a build path, because all nested builds in a composite builds were "flattened". This changed with the introduction of the [qualified build paths](https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/23165). Now, the build-name to build-path is not possible without additional information.

This PR changes the `BuildIdentifier` implementations to be based on an actual build path and introduces a new `getBuildPath(): String` method on the `BuildIdentifier` interface.

Merge pull request #24375 Validate tasks and transforms are not created after configuration cache load

Fixes #24251

Unique ids for `TaskIdentity` and `TransformationNode` are not requested from a shared `BuildTree`-scoped service.

The changes validate the assumption that no tasks or transforms must be created after configuration cache load (in a new build or with load-after-store).

Scenarios:
1. Regular build
    - create new tasks, new transforms
    - (nothing to validate)
2. Build with CC hit
    - (no new tasks or new transforms are created)
    - load tasks, load transforms
    - **error if** trying to create new tasks or transforms after at least one has been loaded
3. Build with CC and load-after-store
    - create new tasks, new transforms
    - store configuration in CC
    - load tasks, load transforms
    - **error if** trying to create new tasks or transforms after at least one has been loaded

Merge pull request #23961 Fix gradlew on systems that don't have which

Fixes #23960

### Context
The `gradlew` script uses either JAVA_HOME or `which` to determine the path to the `java` binary. However, `which` is not available on every system. This causes `gradlew` to fail on systems that neither set the JAVA_HOME environment variable nor have `which` installed.  Instead, we can use `command`, which is both defined by POSIX, and already in use to verify that the `xargs` command is available.

References:
- https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/utilities/command.html

Merge pull request #24280 Run dependency actions on entire hierarchy

Make sure we run the dependency actions on the entire hierarchy before traversing that hierarchy for dependencies and excludes. This is because the dependency actions may themselves modify the hierarchy, so before traversing we need to make sure the hierarchy isn't going to change out from under us.

This should be fine since configurations' dependency actions are idempotent. The actions automatically de-register themselves, so once they're called, they're not triggered for subsequent calls.

Fixes: #24234

Merge pull request #24113 6hundreds/load included build properties

Fixes #19793

In order of restoring CC state we should load included builds Gradle properties. Historically loading  Gradle properties and setting System properties was tightly coupled, we wasn't able to load only Gradle properties without set System properties. But seems like we want to do it:

 - To support System properties of included builds as an inputs for CC, we are tracking them via `EnvironmentChangeTracker` in `DefaultGradlePropertiesLoader`. Later System properties restoring in `ConfigurationCacheState` as a `CCEnvironmentChangeTracker.loadFrom`. After load it's prohibited to use `EnvironmentChangeTracker` for further tracking.

 - After System properties restored, we want to restore Gradle properties for included builds. At this moment we don't want set System properties for them again because it is leads to tracking it via `EnvironmentChangeTracker`, what is prohibited (see above). So we need an ability to conditionally exclude setting System properties from loading Gradle properties.

This PR decoupling `DefaultGradlePropertiesLoader` to few single-responsible services and allows `GradlePropertiesController` to orchestrate them in order to load Gradle properties.

Things WIP:
- [x] Test coverage for new API
- [x] BuildSrc support

Co-authored-by: Sergey Opivalov <sopivalov@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #23927 Relocate Role-Based Configuration classes to make them accessible when creating configurations

`RoleBasedConfigurationContainerInternal` needs to exist in a deeper part of the subproject hierarchy than `dependency-management`, so that the factory method in it can be called from every Gradle subproject creating configurations.

After moving this class to the `core` subproject, the class hierarchy is changed so that `RBCCI` extends `ConfigurationContainerInternal`, instead of the opposite.  This means the create factory methods must return a plain `Configuration`, rather than `ConfigurationInternal`, which is not visible from `core`.  The new internal `ConfigurationRole` interface and `ConfigurationRoles` implementation enum also follow `RBCCI` into core.

The `isCanBeDeclaredAgainst` and `setCanBeDeclaredAgainst` methods, which were previously added to the `ConfigurationInternal` interface to avoid adding to the public `Configuration` API, are now moved to `Configuration` (this puts them next to the equivalent methods for isCanBeConsumed/Resolved, which is a more appropriate place anyway) to be accessible.  They are now marked `@Incubating` since 8.1 for binary compatibility check reasons, though they existed in the internal type hierarchy prior to this.

The `preventUsageMutation` method also has to be accessible from `RBCCI` in core, so it can't remain on `ConfigurationInternal` and so it moves to `DeprecableConfiguration`.  As the `RBCCI` is the only caller of this method outside of `DefaultConfiguration` itself, this shouldn't be a problem.  Even if it makes the interface slightly less cohesive, it doesn't seem worth creating a different new, accessible, sub-interface of Configuration just for this method.

In summary, strictly internal relocations, with the exception of exposing `isCanBeDeclaredAgainst` and `setCanBeDeclaredAgainst` on `Configuration`, which is arguably where they should have been added in the first place.

Co-authored-by: Thomas Tresansky <ttresansky@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #23373 More agent supported modes

## Review notes
This PR adds the ability to use the instrumenting agent in all Gradle integration tests, but using the new instrumentation mode is still gated behind a feature flag, so there are no observable behavior changes (these are to come). As of this PR, you have to specify `-Porg.gradle.integtest.agent.allowed=true` flag to run tests with the new instrumentation mode. The follow-up PR will change the default value of the feature flag.

I strived to make commits self-contained and to avoid back-and-forth, so the PR commits can be reviewed one-by-one. Some TODOs are addressed in the follow-up commits, but several left for coming PRs.

## A summary of changes

A quick recap: there are two essential pieces to make the new instrumentation work. First, the agent has to be applied to the process running the build, and the `DefaultClassFileTransformer` has to be registered within the agent. Second, the `DefaultCachedClasspathTransformer` has to output `TransformedClassPath` instead of `DefaultClassPath`. Prior to this PR, applying the agent would toggle the DefaultCachedClasspathTransformer.

However, to make feature flag working in all modes, we have to break this link. When the build runs in the "--no-daemon" mode (i.e. everything happens in the client process), the agent is being applied with a flag in the start script. It is not possible to figure out the state of the feature flag in the start script. The same applies to the "--foreground" mode of starting the daemon.

This PR introduces the AgentStatus interface that is being controlled by both the presence of the agent and the value of the feature flag. With this, it becomes possible to apply the agent in the start scripts. For foreground daemons, there are changes to the compatibility checking: the `-javaagent:..gradle-instrumentation-agent` switch doesn't affect the compatibility of daemon contexts, as the agent status is present in the context explicitly anyway.

It is not possible for the daemon/process to change its instrumentation mode. The daemon flags (maybe coming from the `gradle.properties` of the first build) at startup determine the mode.

The rest of the changes are mostly dealing with the test infrastructure to allow enabling the new instrumentation in different modes:
1. Embedded mode: agent is applied to test processes, and to the daemons spawned in the tests.
2. No-daemon mode: start script tweaks and process compatibility tweaks (process with agent applied can run tests with legacy instrumentation)
3. Forking mode: it was working already.

In the end, when  `-Porg.gradle.integtest.agent.allowed=true` is used, all executors enable the feature flag in their command line.

## Follow-up work
- TAPI tests are not executed with the agent instrumentation enabled. This is going to be revisited when the feature flag becomes on by default. It is just too hard to plumb the feature flag all the way for TAPI.
- A few tests are ignored for now, but the breakages are not really affecting correctness.

Part of #23297.

Co-authored-by: Mikhail Lopatkin <mlopatkin@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #23711 Further Simplify Capabilities Type Hierarchy

Adds a `CapabilitiesMetadataInternal` interface extending `CapabilitiesMetadata` to simplify the hierarchy and type calculations

This allows the `isShadowedCapabilityOnly` method to exist as a normal instance method on this new type, rather than an external
static instanceof check. It requires moving some of the internal `Capability` defining interfaces to the core-api project (they remain internal)
and does not add any new public apis.

It also makes `ShadowedCapability` extend `ImmutableCapability`, which allows for the deletion of the `ShadowedSingleImmutableCapabilities`
extension.

New Hierarchies:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44197/215541532-9389cd7b-f997-495d-840b-5b50392014dc.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44197/215534649-237c8b8d-0031-4223-a2cd-ed160ce5f782.png)
* Note that `MutableCapabilitiesMetadata` can't simply extend `CapabilitiesMetadataInternal` because public API can't extend internal types, otherwise this would be another simplification to do.

Old Hierarchies:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44197/215539718-3de51d35-1eec-42e0-8487-997e55b9c6b9.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44197/215539509-c73d004e-1b3d-48a7-8aef-f36edadc843f.png)

There is also a not pictured "new" `org.gradle.internal.component.external.model.ImmutableCapabilities` class recreated to support AGP and KGP.  It was always internal, but possibly we'd want to add deprecation warnings in its constructor.  It should not be used and should be deleted once these plugins migrate off of it.

This change is binary incompatible but standalone scripts are recompiled for each new Gradle version anyway. The change is source compatible.

This also allows us to get rid of the legacy `InitScriptApi` and `SettingsScriptApi` types, and also `GradleDelegate`, `SettingsDelegate` and `ProjectDelegate` types.

The PR also moves all Kotlin DSL script templates away from the old Kotlin scripting annotations except for features not supported yet in the new annotations. Using the new ones allows moving common script templates configuration to a central place.

* Fixes https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/23496

Co-authored-by: Paul Merlin <paul@gradle.com>

<!--- Why do you believe many users will benefit from this change? -->
These fixes will reduce the inconsistency in the documentation.
The current documentation configures the test engine in several different ways, which leads to misunderstandings.
Before:
```bash
$ grep -F -e 'useJUnitPlatform()' -B 2 -r --include 'build.gradle*' --with-filename . | grep -F -e '{' | grep --only-matching -E -e 'build.gradle.*' | sed 's/-/: /' | sort | uniq -c
      1 build.gradle.kts: tasks.named<Test>("test") {
      3 build.gradle.kts: tasks.test {
      3 build.gradle.kts: tasks.withType<Test>().configureEach {
      1 build.gradle: tasks.named("test") {
      3 build.gradle: tasks.named('test') {
      1 build.gradle: tasks.named('test', Test) {
      6 build.gradle: tasks.withType(Test).configureEach {
      3 build.gradle: test {
```
After:
```bash
$ grep -F -e 'useJUnitPlatform()' -B 2 -r --include 'build.gradle*' --with-filename . | grep -F -e '{' | grep --only-matching -E -e 'build.gradle.*' | sed 's/-/: /' | sort | uniq -c
      7 build.gradle.kts: tasks.test {
     14 build.gradle: test {
```

Merge pull request #23264 Intercept instrumentable classloaders in the agent

This PR tags all classloaders that are intended for the configuration cache instrumentation with the `InstrumentedClassLoader` interface. The `DefaultClassFileTransformer` hooks into the Java Agent at the daemon start, looks for classes loaded with the classloader implementing the marker interface, and asks the class loaders to further instrument the classes.

How to decide if the classloader should become instrumentable? We wrap all `ClassPath` returned from the instrumentation facility with `TransformedClassPath`, and all operations (except converting `ClassPath` to the list of files and assembling back) keep the `transformed` status. When turning the `TransformedClassPath` into the class loader, the proper class loader type is used.

The feature is under the opt-in feature flag, so no changes of behavior unless you explicitly opt in.

Part of #22939

This is part 2/3. The prev part is #23123. The next part is #23278.

Co-authored-by: Mikhail Lopatkin <mlopatkin@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #23164 Partially move to JB nullness annotations, annotate some APIs with correct nullness

Includes #23122. Fixes #12388.

Kotlin DSL can now use `CopySpec#filter`, `CopySpec#rename`, `Provider#map`, `Provider#flatMap` with `null`. Most other APIs will also accept `null` now, which may be incorrect. A follow-up PR to enforce annotating `Transformer` will follow at some point to correct this.

Additionally, the nullness is only fully correct under Kotlin language version 1.7. We are still using 1.5, so annotating with `@NotNull` in generics doesn't work properly yet. We are hoping we can just move to 1.7+ as a part of 8.0, so there is no problems with this.

This PR is mainly a big deal because it moves `Transformer` to `core-api`, in order to annotate it properly (requires Java 8 / TYPE_USE annotations). This also means making a new type for everything in Java 6 (`InternalTransformer`), moving the deprecated `CollectionUtils` to Java 8, migrating the newer `internal.CollectionUtils` to `InternalTransformer`, and much more related to this move. We investigated other options and found they were lacking:
- Forbid `@Nullable` `Provider#flatMap` (can be replaced with `Providers#empty` (new API); but this does not fix other potentially problematic APIs (e.g. `CopySpec#filter`))
- Make `Transformer#transform` `@Nullable` (may make some APIs incorrect, in a way that cannot be fixed)

We chose to do this third option:
- Move `Transformer` into core-api so it can be marked `@Nullable` properly (may break binary compatibility with some plugins?)

If a plugin managed to use the Java 6 Transformer and cannot function with the Java 8 version that is now in the `core-api` JAR instead of the `base-services` JAR, this would be a breaking change for it. However, all of our `Transformer` APIs are Java 8, so it should be possible to migrate any usage of our API since it will already require Java 8. It would only be internal APIs or non-API usage that might break. This risk was considered acceptable by me and @jvandort.

We are open to other suggestions, though it might mean moving this PR out of 8.0 depending on complexity.

Co-authored-by: Sterling Greene <sterling@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #23054 Use abstract task subclasses for Gradle 8+ when checking binary compatibility

In Gradle 8 all the task classes have been converted to being abstract with the intention of using injected properties in the form of abstract methods. This in turn forces all task sub-classes to be abstract too (not technically, but from the best practice point of view).

When we check for binary compatibility of task sub-classes compiled with Gradle 8+ we should make them abstract as well.

Merge pull request #22739 Move task property exploration around

This is a step towards extracting work property exploration into a general concept in `:execution`. Well, actually several steps.

This all is part of a larger effort to consolidate property handling across tasks and transforms, simplifying the code, making it less error-prone, and adding the possibility for reuse (e.g. adding the ability to reuse `@ServiceReference` for transforms, enabling consistent finalization of properties across different types of work, or capturing inputs for worker actions in the future etc.). Another goal with the consolidation is to clarify ownership.

The idea in this PR is to move things _towards_ the following locations:

- `:model-core` should have everything about annotations and generic type metadata handling (no mention of concrete annotations except for `@Nested`)
- `:execution` should have type metadata handlers that are related to common annotations used on all executable work types: `@Input`, `@InputFile` (yes, the annotations still mostly live in `org.gradle.api.tasks`, we won't fix that here)
- `:core` should have logic related to task-specific annotations (`@CacheableTask`, `@OutputFile` etc.)
- `:dependency-management` should have logic related to transforms only (`@CacheableTransform`, `@InputArtifact` and friends)

Note that there are several loose ends. Also note that some types were first moved to `:model-core` only to be then moved to `:execution` or `:core`.

Merge pull request #22206 Implement injectable shared build services

Fixes: #16168

Expands on #21754 to use conventions to resolve services by name
Adds buildService snippet variant that uses ServiceReference

### New `@ServiceReference` annotation
Properties can now be marked as service references.

* without a string value, dispenses with the need to call `Task.usesService()`, but a value needs to be set before the property can be used to access the service
* with a string value (the name of the service being consumed), is similar to setting the corresponding build service provider reference as a convention, dispensing with the need to set a value, and to call `Task.usesService()`
* service references are ignored for any input/output up-to-date checking, just like `@Internal` properties
* Suggestions of a better name are welcome.

### New "smart collection" for handling a task's required services

* Handles service references declared using the new annotation or explicitly set using `Task.usesService()` uniformly (see `DetaultTaskRequiredServices`)
* Expanded `PropertyVisitor` and new `PropertyAnnotationHandler` to support visiting properties marked as service references (in addition to inputs, outputs etc) via annotation or using the runtime API

### Changes to `BuildServiceRegistry`  and `BuildServiceProvider`

* Refactored `BuildServiceProvider` into two subclasses: `RegisteredBuildServiceProvider` and `ConsumedBuildServiceProvider `- the former plays the role of the original BSP, namely instantiate the underlying service lazily from a reference obtained directly from a service registration, and the latter allows a consumer to resolve a build service reference based the service name and type alone.
* Moved obtaining a `SharedResource` from a build service provider from `AbstractTask` to `BuildServiceRegistry`.

### Configuration cache implications

* When storing build service provider information, we can store either a `ConsumedBuildServiceProvider` (unresolved) or `RegisteredBuildServiceProvider`(resolved) - when restoring, we always read as resolved providers
* When storing build service providers required by a task, we store both those set explicitly (using Task.usesService()` or declared via annotation as if they were originally set explicitly.

### Additional changes

* Lazily setting a convention to the build service property via instrumentation to double lazily resolve to the registered service provider.
* validation of properties marked as service references and corresponding diagnostic message tests
* one new snippet showing off the new feature
* new integration tests validating the new service declaration syntax
* updates to unit tests that needed upkeeping to handle the new smart collection for managing required services for a task

Co-authored-by: Rafael Chaves <rchaves@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #19965 Use relative paths when comparing outputs

When running Gradle in the same _physical_ location, though with different _logical_ absolute paths, Gradle can get confused with the outputs and produce incorrect results. This can happen when using substituted drives on Windows or when mounting the same file system in different locations on Windows.

Note that this is about running Gradle in the "physically" same project location, not about copying a project. This is about correctness when running Gradle on the same project which is "mounted" by the operating system in different locations.

Fixes #15503

Merge pull request #22677 Verify TestNG parameters in worker

Previously we would load up the test runtime claspath in TestNGTestFramework, then load some TestNG classes to verify which version we are running. Based on the version we performed verification to ensure the user set the test options correctly relative to the version of TestNG they are running.

We were caching this ClassLoader even after the build was complete, thus production jars could have had their files held open after the build was complete. To avoid this, we move the verification to inside the test worker -- when the application classloader already has TestNG on the path. This allows us to not construct the test ClassLoader in the main Gradle daemon, and thus avoid creating a ClassLoader which points at the test runtime classpath and thus the production jars.

Merge pull request #22679 Fix IDE-reported error in `ProblemReportingProject.projectPath`

The IDE would report an error on a nullable `delegate.projectPath` used as the return value of the non-null `Path`. If you change the return type to `Path?`, the compiler reports an error because of the return type not matching the supertype's annotation.

So annotating `ProjectInternal.getProjectPath` with `@Nonnull` seems to be the right way to make both the compiler and the IDE happy with `ProblemReportingProject.projectPath`.

Merge pull request #22565 Create compileElements and add projectInternalView()

Create a new `compileElements` consumable configuration, intended initially to be used by test suites to create unit-test-like test suites. Eventually, we have plans to migrate the default test suite to use this configuration.

`compileElements` acts much like `apiElements` except it provides the "internal view" of a project during compile time instead of the "api view" which projects normally consume during compile-time. This is particularly useful for unit tests, but can also prove useful for writing test fixtures or implementing analytics plugins. By internal view, we mean the entirety of the compile classpath, including `api`, `implementation`, `compileOnly`, and `compileOnlyApi`.

To implement this, we add a new attribute, `CompileView`, which is only applicable when resolving a compile classpath -- or in other words, is only applicable when combined with `Usage#JAVA_API`. We additionally add attribute schema compatibility rules in the `jvm-ecosystem` plugin to ensure that the current behavior remains consistent -- that is, if the `CompileView` attribute is not requested, the default vale of the attribute equates to `CompileView#JAVA_API`, which will resolve `apiElements`.

This new configuration will not be published. The intention is not to resolve this configuration from outside of the project, though this pattern is not explicitly forbidden. We do not restrict users from doing so, however we do not provide any means, via the DSL, to depend on another project's complete compile view. Power users can accomplish this, if they wish, by manually constructing a dependency with the proper attributes, however this is not encouraged for any known use case.

Re-targeting of https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/21830 and https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/21697 after reverting them in 7.6 in https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/22114

Merge pull request #22361 Fix CC compatibility of implicitTaskInputDependency snippet

This doesn't address the root cause: TaskProvider.map {} loses the fact that the resulting value is produced by the task and should not be evaluated by the configuration cache. Provider chain with explicitly present `outputFile` property avoids this pitfall, as this property is declared as "changing content", so the configuration cache stops evaluating the provider's value and stores the transforms instead.

Arguably, using flatMap + map here is cleaner anyway, as calling `Provider.get()` is no longer necessary.

Merge pull request #22114 Revert compileElements

Despite all my attempts to resolve the issues with adding the new `compileElements` configuration and its associated `CompileView` attribute, I was not able to come up with a solution to avoid changes in attribute matching behavior.

Given the way attributes currently work in Gradle, I cannot see how it is possible to add new attributes or update the attributes of existing variants without changing attribute matching behavior in unsuspecting ways.

It is clear that this feature needs some more polish before we decide to merge it. We may end up deciding that this is best targeted to 8.0, where we can accept the minor changes in attribute matching behavior, though this will require future discussion.

For now, we will remove this feature from 7.6.

Merge pull request #22004 Introduce some shared abstractions for build options, internal options and feature previews

<!--- The issue this PR addresses -->
Fixes #?

### Context

Introduce a service to determine the value of an internal option. This service lives with the `BuildOption` types. Refactor a bunch of places that were trying to figure out whether a system property might be set later in the build lifecycle to use this service.

Also move the feature preview service to live with these other types, and allow a feature preview to be enabled by a system property, for those previews that take effect before the settings script is executed, such as 'stable configuration cache'.

This way, an internal option is simply a build option that is not publicly advertised and a feature preview is a boolean build option that can be enabled in the DSL. Over time, these concepts should become more consistent, so that they can all be set persistently using a `gradle.properties` or the DSL, or dynamically calculated by build logic.

Merge pull request #21223 Let the Tooling API control system properties contributed from the client-side

Fixes #17745
Spec: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1eM8E_fajrCF_O-5R-_1VyCuPk4kpW5LJshqcrYZFoxo/edit#

When a client executes a Gradle build invocation via the Tooling API, [all system properties](https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/master/subprojects/launcher/src/main/java/org/gradle/launcher/daemon/configuration/DaemonParameters.java#L154) from the client JVM are passed to the daemon. This is not desired, especially for IntelliJ IDEA, as it uses a large number of system properties that could potentially break the build (e.g. `java.system.class.loader`).

This pull request introduces `LongRunningOperation.withSystemProperties(Map)` to let the TAPI client control what system properties are available for the target build from the client JVM. The exact behavior is defined in [SystemPropertyPropagationCrossVersionTest](https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/21223/files#diff-67f55edd35e95eb55dbb8d746cfe62d9ea174edc8e271dea9c7428abcda76132).

The new API has an effect only if the target Gradle version is >=7.6.

Co-authored-by: Donat Csikos <donat@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #17699 Let eclipse-wtp remove the "jst.utility" facet in ejb modules

Fixes #17681

### Context

<!--- Why do you believe many users will benefit from this change? -->
The gradle _eclipse-wtp_ plugin adds an Eclipse `jst.utility` facet to each java project.
If you want Eclipse IDE to recognize it as  an EJBs project, you have to add a `jst.ejb` facet:

```groovy
eclipse.wtp.facet {
    facet name: 'jst.ejb', version: '3.2'
}
```
However as `jst.ejb` and `jst.utility` facets are incompatible, Eclipe IDE will complain and state that it is misconfigured.

If you use gradle to build projects but want to use the Eclipse  IDE, then the gradle configuration should be considered as the source of truth. However this implies that the _eclipse_ and _eclipse-wtp_ plugins must configure the corresponding Eclipse projects correctly.

In addition, to align with the behavior of the Eclipse IDE wizard, the `jst.ejb` facet should also be defined as `fixed`.

This can be done using the `EclipseWTPFacet.file` method:

```groovy
eclipse.wtp.facet.file.whenMerged { it.facets = it.facets.findAll { it.name != 'jst.utility' }}
```
but, in my opinion, this should be reserved for tricky edge cases not basic project configuration.

That's why I think developers using the Eclipse IDE would benefit from this change.

Relevant forum: https://discuss.gradle.org/t/easily-customize-the-eclipse-wtp-facet-version/8690

#### Remark:

I'm not sure if the `EclipseWTPFacet.facet` method is the right place to add this modification, but I haven't found a better one.

Merge pull request #20609 Replace classycle by archunit test

So that the reporting when we actually have a classycle is better.

The PR replaces our Classycle tasks by an ArchUnit test. The test is defined once in `internal-architecture-testing` and then executed in all subprojects. It only takes the classes of the subprojects into account and does look a cycles between packages in the current project and other projects. The reason for that is that classycle doesn't either and that we have a lot of cycles between subprojects.

For simplicity, the ArchUnit tests only works on the main source set of the production classes. So it doesn't look at test source sets or any other things. I also didn't add these cycle tests for our build logic, since this would require to pull the test even further up. While possible, I am not convinced this is worth the effort.

As a side-effect of the change, you can now define ArchUnit tests simply in the subprojects in the `archUnit` source set. Those ArchUnit test will run against the current project and possible its dependencies.

Co-authored-by: Stefan Wolf <wolf@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #21008 Add property `host` to `JavaDebugOptions`: support debugging via network

In Java 9 and above, if the JDWP arguments only include the port and not the host name, the debugger server will only listen on the loopback network interface, and it won't accept connections via network.

Debugging remotely with explicitly specified host address was only possible by passing the JDWP arguments as a string, which is a UX issue.
Adding a property for specifying the host address to `JavaDebugOptions` fixes that.

Also add daemon parameter property `org.gradle.debug.host`.
This simplifies running the daemon in a way that it is debuggable remotely via network, as opposed to the loopback interface.

Fixes #20644

Co-authored-by: Sergey Igushkin <sigushkin@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #21084 Fix up-to-date checks for named task actions

Fixes #7923

When adding action to a task it is possible to optionally provide a name for the action.
```groovy
doFirst { println("hey") }
doFirst("print info") { println("printing info") }
```

When the action is added via Groovy DSL, in the nameless case an overload of `doFirst` is called that accepts an actual Groovy closure: `doFirst(Closure action)`. However, the case when the name is supplied is handled differently. The only overload of `doFirst` that accepts the name expects the second argument to be an `Action`: `doFirst(String actionName, Action<? super Task> action)`. In order to handle a `Closure` instance coming from Groovy DSL as a second argument Gradle generates an overload at runtime (during classloading). In that generated overload the closure object gets wrapped in the `ConfigureUtil.WrappedConfigureAction`.

Later on, the execution machinery tries to ensure that all actions are inputs-aware, wrapping them in the `AbstractTask.TaskActionWrapper` if they are not already `InputChangesAwareTaskAction`. This second layer of wrapping leads to the fact that the action is never considered to be changed (even if the actual implementation changes), because the implementation is represented as the internal `ConfigureUtil.WrappedConfigureAction` class that never changes during task evaluation.

In order to fix this, the instances of `ConfigureUtil.WrappedConfigureAction` are detected during input-awareness wrapping phase. Then, instead of being wrapped by an `TaskActionWrapper`, the inner closure (actual implementation) is extracted and wrapped by a more appropriate `AbstractTask.ClosureTaskAction`.

All of this symmetrically applies to both `doFirst` and `doLast` calls.

Co-authored-by: Alex Semin <asemin@gradle.com>

Merge pull request #21055 Autodetect Eclipse Temurin runtimes in Windows

<!--- The issue this PR addresses -->

### Context
<!--- Why do you believe many users will benefit from this change? -->
<!--- Link to relevant issues or forum discussions here -->
Adoptium JDK is now under the Eclipse Adoptium/Temurin project.
Newer builds of Adoptium JDK (such as JDK 17) register themselves under a different registry key, `HKLM\Software\Eclipse Adoptium`. Those JDKs are not autodetected by Gradle.

This commit amends the registry lookup logic to also look for this new key.

Implementation note: I explored having the Temurin runtime detection happening under a different method (like `findTemurinOpenJdk`), however given that Temurin *is* the current implementation of AdoptOpenJDK I believe that having that distinction in the code could be misleading because it would imply those are competing runtimes. That option also required marginally more lines of code than the version submitted in this PR.

Merge pull request #20994 Warn user if task option clashes w/ built-in one

In #9166, we added support for --rerun as a built-in task option.
If a task defines its own -rerun option, the built-in is disabled.
This change aims to tell the user of a task that has an option
clashing with a built-in one (and that the built-in is now unavailable).

<!--- The issue this PR addresses -->
Fixes #9166

### Context
<!--- Why do you believe many users will benefit from this change? -->
<!--- Link to relevant issues or forum discussions here -->
The design for #20895 received clear feedback that some sort of warning was required to let users know a custom option clashed with a built-in one. The initial implementation did not address that, this change set aims to address that gap.

Regarding implementation choices, OptionReader was considered too low level to be a proper place to produce any warnings. That is why we expose the clashing status for an option descriptor so a client like `CommandLineTaskConfigurer` can decide what to do with clashing options itself, produce more meaningful messages for the context in hand etc.

### Manual testing

```
~/.gradle/gradle-install/bin/gradle  hello  --message hey -w
Built-in option 'rerun' in  in task :app:hello was disabled for clashing with another option of same name
hello from GreetingTask hey
```

### Gradle Core Team Checklist
- [ ] Verify design and implementation (see #20895)
- [ ] Verify test coverage and CI build status (see #20895)
- [ ] Verify documentation (see #20978)

Merge pull request #6682 from gradle/lptr/core/upgrade-to-groovy-2.5

Changes:

- Upgraded to Groovy 2.5.2.

    This required building our own `groovy-all.jar` (see https://github.com/gradle/gradle-groovy-all), because Groovy 2.5 stopped shipping the uber-jar and replaced it with a BOM. I tried to use the separate JARs, but it poses a number of issues, most importantly that the increased length of the classpath breaks our Windows tests. So we decided to go with repackaging Groovy. In the future it would be nice to remove the need for the repackaging, and maybe even remove some of the Groovy libs. I mean, c'mon, we ship classes from `groovy-swing`!

- Downgraded `opentest4j` to work around https://github.com/ota4j-team/opentest4j/issues/49, introduced by an upgrade in TestNG.
- Upgraded compiler memory in IntelliJ from 2 GB to 3 GB because Groovy compilation with 2.5 seemed to slow down a lot, and produce OOMEs occasionally. With the increased amount of memory Groovy compilation is actually quite snappy.
- Replaced calls to `DateGroovyMethods` extension methods. This led to the realization that some of our timeouts mistakenly use days instead of milliseconds. We should fix these separately, added `TODO`s.
- Bumped Spock to the Groovy 2.5 variant and fixed a number of issues with our tests. Some of these issues are valid ones, others seem to indicate bugs in either the Groovy compiler or Spock. Reported the issue to Spock: https://github.com/spockframework/spock/issues/880

    The `Specification` class added by @ldaley to fix type inference in IntelliJ doesn't work anymore unfortunately. I left the code commented out so it's easy to fix it if someone wants to.

- Groovy 2.5 adds local variable type information that needs to be remapped in our script remapper, so I added that.
- Groovy 2.5 uses the `ExtensionModule` mechanism slightly differently which necessitated the exposure of some more packages and resources from `gradleApi()` (see changes in `DefaultGradleApiSpecProvider.java`)
- Replaced references to types in `com.sun.jdi` in `JDWPUtil` with reflection to work around an IntelliJ bug we hit: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/oauth?state=%2Fissue%2FIDEA-198715
- There is some weirdness wrt Tooling API progress tests where the order of events seems to have changed somewhat. See changes in `ToolingApiBuildExecutionCrossVersionSpec.groovy` and `ToolingApiModelCrossVersionSpec.groovy`.
- Stopped using Groovy JSON in `:buildSrc:binaryCompatibilityCheck` because of a classloading issue with Groovy's `FastStringUtils`.

Merge pull request #3619: Further improvements to DependencyMetadata

These changes complete a fairly major refactoring of the `DependencyMetadata` API and the Ivy/Maven implementations.

- Avoid `Set` in the API to avoid use of `LinkedHashSet` internally
- Cache Maven-sourced metadata in a form that closer to the source: avoid converting into Ivy abstractions

Merge pull request #3399: Convert all maven-publish tests to produce and verify Gradle metadata

With this change, all subtypes of `AbstractMavenPublishIntegrationTest` will enable production of Gradle metadata by setting the `-Dorg.gradle.internal.publishGradleMetadata` flag. Only java components are currently published to Gradle metadata, and in these cases the published `.module` file is validated.

There are a couple of exceptions to this:

- Gradle metadata does not yet support dependency excludes. For these cases, the `.module` file is successfully produced, but published dependencies do not have any exclusions. Tests for this functionality have been converted, but we do not attempt to resolve the published `.module` file or verify the published dependencies.
- Where the original component artifacts are modified via the `MavenPublication`, Gradle cannot produce a valid metadata file, and attempting to publish will fail. Module metadata publishing has been disabled for tests that exercise this functionality.

Merge pull request #3349 from gradle/dd/maven-publish-gradle-metadata/basic-java-library

Publish Gradle metadata for java component with dependencies

Allows the maven-publish plugin to produce a Gradle .module metadata file when publishing a Java component. This feature is not yet enabled by default, and must be explicitly enabled by the magic system property org.gradle.internal.publishJavaModuleMetadata.

Changed the Jvm algorightm fpr finding the executables:

-We no longer delegate to ant. This means less dependencies but (very unlikely) might be a breaking change.
-We discover javaHome on creation of the Jvm object. This is much cleaner now.
-We use the same algorithm for finding executables as for finding other things (tools.jar, etc)
-If executable cannot be found with user-supplied java home we fail with a decent exception
-If executable cannot be found with default java home:
-- we search it on the path.
-- if it is not on the path we assume it can be ran in a current folder (backwards compatibility) and print a warning.

Removes extension of archives by default and ensures that jar/war products are built by default.

Jar is added to runtime configuration, so picked up by dependent products, and jar/war tasks can remain enabled all the time.  Jar and War products are still not added to archives by default, but these changes make that more readily possible in the future.

Patch submitted by Spencer Allain.

Merged from the branch. Refactorings in the daemon area. Main goal was to have single registry file for all daemons. Details:
- enabled DaemonFunctionalTest because it should be stable now
- simplified the daemon registry, now daemons are keyed by Address
- added a little bit coverage in the core/caching to understand the code better
- improved SimpleStateCache and added an update method to accompany existing set & get methods
- added some naive synchronization to the DaemonRegistry because it proved problematic in multithreaded environment. It can be improved for better performance.
